values.description:
REGRESSION_846_typo_in_camera has been [failing in Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-raring-amd64/312/consoleFull) for machines without a GPU due to a recent change in pull request #830. This pull request makes that test require DRI, so it won't run on the machines without GPU's.

~~~
155: [ RUN      ] Issue846Test.CaptureData
155: 
155: [1;32mMsg[0m Waiting for master[1;32mMsg[0m Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
155: [1;32mMsg[0m Publicized address: 192.168.1.19
155: [1;31mError [RenderEngine.cc:636][0m Can't open display: 
155: [1;33mWarning [RenderEngine.cc:92][0m Unable to create X window. Rendering will be disabled
155: [1;36mDbg[0m ServerFixture load in 0.03 seconds, timeout after 60 seconds
155: [1;31mError [ServerFixture.cc:199][0m Unable to load the rendering scene.
155: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-default-devel-raring-amd64/gazebo/test/ServerFixture.cc:842: Failure
155: Failed
155: ServerFixture timeout (wait more than 0s): while waiting to load rendering scene
155: Test will failREGRESSION_846_typo_in_camera: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:424: T* boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::rendering::Scene]: Assertion `px != 0' failed.
~~~
I started a [gazebo-any job without a GPU to test this branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/10/)

UPDATE: the [gazebo-any job for this branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/10/) has all tests passing, though there were a few style errors on default, that I fixed in f60ea61.
values.title: Fix 846 regression test by making it a DRI test

values.description:
Although pull request #848 worked with 1.9, it caused a consistent test failure and deprecation warning after being merged forward into 2.0. This fixes both issues.

[Jenkins test failure and compiler warning](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-gazebo_2.1-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/29/)

[Jenkins test of this branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/75/) shows the warning and sonar test are fixed (though there is an unrelated failure of GpuLaser_TEST)

UPDATE: retarget to gazebo_2.1
values.title: Fix sonar test and deprecation warning

values.description:
Thanks to pull request #827, we can compile gazebo on OSX 10.9, but it seg-faults when attempting to load an empty world (#965). A backtrace indicated problems with `Base::childrenEnd`. In my reading of the code, it appears to be used as a cached value of the `end()` method of the `Base::children` vector. To me it seems dangerous, so I've just replaced it with `children.end()`. We may choose to remove this value in the default branch.

I haven't done any profiling on the performance impact of this change. Please speak up if you think this is the wrong approach.

[jenkins test build successful](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/76)
values.title: Fix memory access bugs with libc++ on mavericks (#965)

summary.raw:
Thanks to pull request #827, we can compile gazebo on OSX 10.9, but it seg-faults when attempting to load an empty world (#965). A backtrace indicated problems with `Base::childrenEnd`. In my reading of the code, it appears to be used as a cached value of the `end()` method of the `Base::children` vector. To me it seems dangerous, so I've just replaced it with `children.end()`. We may choose to remove this value in the default branch.

I haven't done any profiling on the performance impact of this change. Please speak up if you think this is the wrong approach.

[jenkins test build successful](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/76)
summary.html:
Thanks to pull request #827, we can compile gazebo on OSX 10.9, but it seg-faults when attempting to load an empty world (#965). A backtrace indicated problems with Base::childrenEnd. In my reading of the code, it appears to be used as a cached value of the end() method of the Base::children vector. To me it seems dangerous, so I've just replaced it with children.end(). We may choose to remove this value in the default branch.

I haven't done any profiling on the performance impact of this change. Please speak up if you think this is the wrong approach.

jenkins test build successful

values.description:
Issue #947 was mostly fixed by pull request #827, but there is one lingering compilation error on mavericks due to tuple syntax. Since the tr1 headers are not available in libc++, gtest implements their own version of a few of these calls. They don't implement the `tr1::tie` call, however; so `tr1::get<int>` must be used instead.

UPDATE: [Jenkins test build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/12/) successful, aside from the Sonar test failure addressed by pull request #856

UPDATE: re-targeted to gazebo_2.1
values.title: Use different tuple syntax to fix compilation on OSX mavericks

values.description:
Several joint tests involving ForceTorque measurement required bullet >= 2.82, which is now a version requirement on the default branch. This pull request enables the ForceTorque1 and ForceTorque2 tests for bullet.

Additionally, the test cases are streamlined by using `TEST_P` to instantiate the test cases for each physics engine. Each TEST_P instance is also moved to the same location in the file.

The GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce does not currently work due to issue #619, so a corresponding error message is added.
values.title: Enable Joint ForceTorque Tests for Bullet (#970)

summary.raw:
Several joint tests involving ForceTorque measurement required bullet >= 2.82, which is now a version requirement on the default branch. This pull request enables the ForceTorque1 and ForceTorque2 tests for bullet.

Additionally, the test cases are streamlined by using `TEST_P` to instantiate the test cases for each physics engine. Each TEST_P instance is also moved to the same location in the file.

The GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce does not currently work due to issue #619, so a corresponding error message is added.
summary.html:
Several joint tests involving ForceTorque measurement required bullet >= 2.82, which is now a version requirement on the default branch. This pull request enables the ForceTorque1 and ForceTorque2 tests for bullet.

Additionally, the test cases are streamlined by using TEST_P to instantiate the test cases for each physics engine. Each TEST_P instance is also moved to the same location in the file.

The GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce does not currently work due to issue #619, so a corresponding error message is added.

values.title: fix for issue #864, enabling Link::SetForce and Link::GetWorldForce for Bullet and Simbody.  Added a check in test for Link::GetWorldForce.

values.description:
## Issue description (pasted from #978):

There is an error when inserting a model like the following that has a single link connected to the world, and the model pose is specified, but no link pose:
~~~
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.4">
  <model name="model">
    <pose>1 2 3 0 0 0</pose>
    <link name="child" />
    <joint name="joint" type="revolute">
      <parent>world</parent>
      <child>child</child>
      <axis>
        <xyz>1.0 0.0 0.0</xyz>
      </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>
~~~
In this case, since the pose offsets are zero for the child link and joint, the joint anchor location should be at 1, 2, 3, 0, 0, 0. In practice, the joint anchor is being placed at the origin.

## Pull request summary

I added a test for this issue in 15cf96c, adding a slight modification to Joint_TEST::SpawnJoint. The fix in 597aa5c is a one-liner, basically to always execute some code that initializes the pose of an entity relative to its parent, even if an sdf child pose offset is not provided (it will just be set to the default value of all zeros if not provided). I had to disable the test for simbody though (3831300) since SimbodyJoint::GetAnchor isn't yet implemented.

## Jenkins verification

Started two jobs that had failing tests in INTEGRATION_imu:

 * [gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/83](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/83/) 
 * [gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/14](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/14/)

So I started two more jobs, but these failed because gazebosim.org was down:

 * [gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/85](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/85/)
 * [gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/15](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/15/)

So I started two more jobs:

 * [gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/16](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/16/)
 * [gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/87](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/87/)
values.title: Fix joint anchor when link pose not specified (#978)

There is an error when inserting a model like the following that has a single link connected to the world, and the model pose is specified, but no link pose:
~~~
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.4">
  <model name="model">
    <pose>1 2 3 0 0 0</pose>
    <link name="child" />
    <joint name="joint" type="revolute">
      <parent>world</parent>
      <child>child</child>
      <axis>
        <xyz>1.0 0.0 0.0</xyz>
      </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>
~~~
In this case, since the pose offsets are zero for the child link and joint, the joint anchor location should be at 1, 2, 3, 0, 0, 0. In practice, the joint anchor is being placed at the origin.

## Pull request summary

I added a test for this issue in 15cf96c, adding a slight modification to Joint_TEST::SpawnJoint. The fix in 597aa5c is a one-liner, basically to always execute some code that initializes the pose of an entity relative to its parent, even if an sdf child pose offset is not provided (it will just be set to the default value of all zeros if not provided). I had to disable the test for simbody though (3831300) since SimbodyJoint::GetAnchor isn't yet implemented.

summary.html:
Issue description (pasted from #978):

There is an error when inserting a model like the following that has a single link connected to the world, and the model pose is specified, but no link pose:

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.4">
  <model name="model">
    <pose>1 2 3 0 0 0</pose>
    <link name="child" />
    <joint name="joint" type="revolute">
      <parent>world</parent>
      <child>child</child>
      <axis>
        <xyz>1.0 0.0 0.0</xyz>
      </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>

In this case, since the pose offsets are zero for the child link and joint, the joint anchor location should be at 1, 2, 3, 0, 0, 0. In practice, the joint anchor is being placed at the origin.

Pull request summary

I added a test for this issue in 15cf96c, adding a slight modification to Joint_TEST::SpawnJoint. The fix in 597aa5c is a one-liner, basically to always execute some code that initializes the pose of an entity relative to its parent, even if an sdf child pose offset is not provided (it will just be set to the default value of all zeros if not provided). I had to disable the test for simbody though (3831300) since SimbodyJoint::GetAnchor isn't yet implemented.

Jenkins verification

Started two jobs that had failing tests in INTEGRATION_imu:

  • gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/83
  • gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/14

So I started two more jobs, but these failed because gazebosim.org was down:

  • gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/85
  • gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/15

So I started two more jobs:

  • gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/16
  • gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/87

values.description:
This pull requests adds a plugin to allow breakable joints. The plugin can be attached to a joint force-torque sensor with a breaking force threshold specified in parameter `<breaking_force_N>`. If a force is detected that exceeds a specified threshold, then the joint is detached. An example model has been uploaded to [gazebo_models in branch breakable_test](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/commits/07116279eae8cf84d160132f26a03ca1153a3b8a). I have tested it with ODE and Bullet; it won't work in Simbody or DART due to #862 and #903.

The plugin required an API addition to ForceTorqueSensor in order to access the parent joint. I've started an [ABI-checker on Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-quantal-amd64/36/).

EDIT: Test with [gazebo_models pull request 70](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/70/test-model-for-breakable-walls/diff).
values.title: Breakable joint plugin

summary.raw:
This pull requests adds a plugin to allow breakable joints. The plugin can be attached to a joint force-torque sensor with a breaking force threshold specified in parameter `<breaking_force_N>`. If a force is detected that exceeds a specified threshold, then the joint is detached. An example model has been uploaded to [gazebo_models in branch breakable_test](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/commits/07116279eae8cf84d160132f26a03ca1153a3b8a). I have tested it with ODE and Bullet; it won't work in Simbody or DART due to #862 and #903.

The plugin required an API addition to ForceTorqueSensor in order to access the parent joint. I've started an [ABI-checker on Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-quantal-amd64/36/).

EDIT: Test with [gazebo_models pull request 70](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/70/test-model-for-breakable-walls/diff).
summary.html:
This pull requests adds a plugin to allow breakable joints. The plugin can be attached to a joint force-torque sensor with a breaking force threshold specified in parameter <breaking_force_N>. If a force is detected that exceeds a specified threshold, then the joint is detached. An example model has been uploaded to gazebo_models in branch breakable_test. I have tested it with ODE and Bullet; it won't work in Simbody or DART due to #862 and #903.

The plugin required an API addition to ForceTorqueSensor in order to access the parent joint. I've started an ABI-checker on Jenkins.

EDIT: Test with gazebo_models pull request 70.

values.description:
Added a dirty flag for `SimbodyLink::SetGravityMode` so actual work is done in the main physics thread to avoid race condition.

Increased box geometry -> simbody brick resolution from 2 to 8, see issue #980.
values.title: patches to get drcsim working with simbody

values.description:
From #982:

I've seen a few failures of the [ForceTorqueSensor_TEST/CreateForceTorque test](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-raring-amd64/321/testReport/junit/%28root%29/ForceTorqueSensor_TEST/CreateForceTorque/), which appear to be caused by an uninitialized variable (failure at [gazebo/sensors/ForceTorqueSensor_TEST.cc:68](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/gazebo/sensors/ForceTorqueSensor_TEST.cc#cl-68):
~~~
gazebo/sensors/ForceTorqueSensor_TEST.cc:68
Value of: math::Vector3(0, 0, 0)
  Actual: 0 0 0
Expected: sensor->GetTorque()
Which is: 2.42305e+242 -3.13745e+242 0
~~~

I initially thought that the wrenchMsg in [ForceTorqueSensor::GetForce](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/gazebo/sensors/ForceTorqueSensor.cc#cl-93) was uninitialized, so I added a test to UNIT_msgs_TEST, but that wasn't the problem. I left the test anyway.

I then tracked down the dJointFeedback struct which contains several vector and is allocated without initializing them in `ODEJoint::SetProvideFeedback`, so I made sure to initialize them.
values.title: Fix uninitialized value (#982)

summary.raw:
From #982:

I've seen a few failures of the [ForceTorqueSensor_TEST/CreateForceTorque test](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-raring-amd64/321/testReport/junit/%28root%29/ForceTorqueSensor_TEST/CreateForceTorque/), which appear to be caused by an uninitialized variable (failure at [gazebo/sensors/ForceTorqueSensor_TEST.cc:68](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/gazebo/sensors/ForceTorqueSensor_TEST.cc#cl-68):
~~~
gazebo/sensors/ForceTorqueSensor_TEST.cc:68
Value of: math::Vector3(0, 0, 0)
  Actual: 0 0 0
Expected: sensor->GetTorque()
Which is: 2.42305e+242 -3.13745e+242 0
~~~

I initially thought that the wrenchMsg in [ForceTorqueSensor::GetForce](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/gazebo/sensors/ForceTorqueSensor.cc#cl-93) was uninitialized, so I added a test to UNIT_msgs_TEST, but that wasn't the problem. I left the test anyway.

I then tracked down the dJointFeedback struct which contains several vector and is allocated without initializing them in `ODEJoint::SetProvideFeedback`, so I made sure to initialize them.
summary.html:
From #982:

I've seen a few failures of the ForceTorqueSensor_TEST/CreateForceTorque test, which appear to be caused by an uninitialized variable (failure at gazebo/sensors/ForceTorqueSensor_TEST.cc:68:

gazebo/sensors/ForceTorqueSensor_TEST.cc:68
Value of: math::Vector3(0, 0, 0)
  Actual: 0 0 0
Expected: sensor->GetTorque()
Which is: 2.42305e+242 -3.13745e+242 0

I initially thought that the wrenchMsg in ForceTorqueSensor::GetForce was uninitialized, so I added a test to UNIT_msgs_TEST, but that wasn't the problem. I left the test anyway.

I then tracked down the dJointFeedback struct which contains several vector and is allocated without initializing them in ODEJoint::SetProvideFeedback, so I made sure to initialize them.

values.description:
Refactor `Noise` class, and add a `GaussianNoise` subclass.

Enable users to use their own custom noise implementation from a sensor plugin by setting noise type to `custom`.

Add an example world [ray_noise_plugin.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/871/custom-sensor-noise/diff#chg-sdf/worlds/ray_noise_plugin.world) that demonstrates using a custom noise model from within [RaySensorNoisePlugin](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/871/custom-sensor-noise/diff#chg-plugins/RaySensorNoisePlugin.cc)

Feel free to suggest improvements to API and design
values.title: Custom sensor noise

summary.raw:
Refactor `Noise` class, and add a `GaussianNoise` subclass.

Enable users to use their own custom noise implementation from a sensor plugin by setting noise type to `custom`.

Add an example world [ray_noise_plugin.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/871/custom-sensor-noise/diff#chg-sdf/worlds/ray_noise_plugin.world) that demonstrates using a custom noise model from within [RaySensorNoisePlugin](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/871/custom-sensor-noise/diff#chg-plugins/RaySensorNoisePlugin.cc)

Feel free to suggest improvements to API and design
summary.html:
Refactor Noise class, and add a GaussianNoise subclass.

Enable users to use their own custom noise implementation from a sensor plugin by setting noise type to custom.

Add an example world ray_noise_plugin.world that demonstrates using a custom noise model from within RaySensorNoisePlugin

Feel free to suggest improvements to API and design

values.description:
There have been some sporadic test failures involving simbody documented in #918. We recently diagnosed the problem as a lack of thread-safety in some SimbodyPhysics API calls (GetWorldLinearVel, GetWorldAngularVel, etc). The test was failing very sporadically, but I made a physics_thread_safe test that fails consistently (`hg pull && hg up fa96c88`, then build and run test INTEGRATION_physics_thread_safe). I fixed the test in 099bf8c by locking the physics update mutex inside SimbodyLink.

I had accidentally based those commits off of default, so I rebranched from gazebo_2.1 for purposes of this pull request. I mention those other commits to tell the story and in case you want to verify the failing test.
values.title: Make some SimbodyLink::Get* functions thread-safe (#918)

values.description:
Issue was that two cameras were producing the same images. One camera was overwriting the buffer before the other one reads it out. To reproduce: put two cameras side by side and a object between them, then look at the camera images in topic viewer.

Added an integration test.
values.title: Fix camera sensor images

summary.raw:
Issue was that two cameras were producing the same images. One camera was overwriting the buffer before the other one reads it out. To reproduce: put two cameras side by side and a object between them, then look at the camera images in topic viewer.

Added an integration test.

Issue was that two cameras were producing the same images. One camera was overwriting the buffer before the other one reads it out. To reproduce: put two cameras side by side and a object between them, then look at the camera images in topic viewer.

Added an integration test.

values.description:
As noted in #983 by @hugomatic , the gazebo log file to which `gzlog` statements are directed can grow very rapidly with messages like:
~~~
[1386972942 867748431] ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldLinearVel returns default of 0 0 0
[1386972942 867757777] ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldTorque returns default of 0 0 0
[1386972942 867766773] ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldForce returns default of 0 0 0
[1386972942 867775745] ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldForce returns default of 0 0 0
[1386972942 867786651] ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldAngularVel returns default of 0 0 0
~~~
The bulk of these messages occur when data logging is on. To reproduce, simply run `gazebo -r` for a few minutes and note the size of `~/.gazebo/gzserver.log`. These messages are generated by the ground plane (or any other static models for that matter) at every time step by the gazebo logger.

The main fix for the large file size is in 23582bd. I also changed the messages to use scoped names in 68fab86 to simplify debugging. Then I felt like I was on a roll and cleaned up these ODELink gzlog messages, so that there should be none in normal operation.
values.title: Suppress spurious gzlog messages (#983)

[1386972942 867766773] ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldForce returns default of 0 0 0
[1386972942 867775745] ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldForce returns default of 0 0 0
[1386972942 867786651] ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldAngularVel returns default of 0 0 0
~~~
The bulk of these messages occur when data logging is on. To reproduce, simply run `gazebo -r` for a few minutes and note the size of `~/.gazebo/gzserver.log`. These messages are generated by the ground plane (or any other static models for that matter) at every time step by the gazebo logger.

The main fix for the large file size is in 23582bd. I also changed the messages to use scoped names in 68fab86 to simplify debugging. Then I felt like I was on a roll and cleaned up these ODELink gzlog messages, so that there should be none in normal operation.

[1386972942 867748431] ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldLinearVel returns default of 0 0 0
[1386972942 867757777] ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldTorque returns default of 0 0 0

[1386972942 867786651] ODE body for link [link] does not exist, GetWorldAngularVel returns default of 0 0 0

The bulk of these messages occur when data logging is on. To reproduce, simply run gazebo -r for a few minutes and note the size of ~/.gazebo/gzserver.log. These messages are generated by the ground plane (or any other static models for that matter) at every time step by the gazebo logger.

The main fix for the large file size is in 23582bd. I also changed the messages to use scoped names in 68fab86 to simplify debugging. Then I felt like I was on a roll and cleaned up these ODELink gzlog messages, so that there should be none in normal operation.

values.description:
Here is a little christmas pull request.

All command line tools have been refactored into one unified tool: `gz`. This matches functionality of other tools, like `hg` and `git`.

The usage is now: `gz <command> [options]`, where <commands> are string like "topic", "log", "joint", etc.

A complete list of commands is available by using `gz` with no arguments.

Help on each command is available using `gz help <command>`

Tab completion is also in effect. You'll need to manually install this file using: `sudo cp tools/gazebo.bash-completion /etc/bash_completion.d/`. This file will be installed when installing from [debian](#!/osrf/gazebo-release/pull-request/12/support-to-install-bash-completion-script/diff).
values.title: New command line tool

summary.raw:
Here is a little christmas pull request.

All command line tools have been refactored into one unified tool: `gz`. This matches functionality of other tools, like `hg` and `git`.

The usage is now: `gz <command> [options]`, where <commands> are string like "topic", "log", "joint", etc.

A complete list of commands is available by using `gz` with no arguments.

Help on each command is available using `gz help <command>`

Tab completion is also in effect. You'll need to manually install this file using: `sudo cp tools/gazebo.bash-completion /etc/bash_completion.d/`. This file will be installed when installing from [debian](#!/osrf/gazebo-release/pull-request/12/support-to-install-bash-completion-script/diff).
summary.html:
Here is a little christmas pull request.

All command line tools have been refactored into one unified tool: gz. This matches functionality of other tools, like hg and git.

The usage is now: gz <command> [options], where <commands> are string like "topic", "log", "joint", etc.

A complete list of commands is available by using gz with no arguments.

Help on each command is available using gz help <command>

Tab completion is also in effect. You'll need to manually install this file using: sudo cp tools/gazebo.bash-completion /etc/bash_completion.d/. This file will be installed when installing from debian.

values.description:
When running the simulator, the collision element we try to access in Gazebo is named `__default__`, but when imported from urdf, the name is `linkname_collision` by default.

This is probably not a proper fix, but I don't know enough about the code to find a cleaner solution.
values.title: Fixing the ContactSensor in Gazebo

summary.raw:
When running the simulator, the collision element we try to access in Gazebo is named `__default__`, but when imported from urdf, the name is `linkname_collision` by default.

This is probably not a proper fix, but I don't know enough about the code to find a cleaner solution.
summary.html:
When running the simulator, the collision element we try to access in Gazebo is named __default__, but when imported from urdf, the name is linkname_collision by default.

This is probably not a proper fix, but I don't know enough about the code to find a cleaner solution.

values.title: Add test based on test_friction.world

summary.html:
@hsu and I have been using the test_friction.world as an informal friction test, so I decided to add an official integration test for it.

The world involves several boxes on the ground plane with a reoriented gravity vector that simulates a 45 degree inclined plane. Each box has a coefficient of friction near 1.0. The boxes with a friction coefficient of 1.0 or greater should not slide, while the boxes with a friction coefficient less than 1.0 should slide. I wrote this test with expectations on the velocity value over 10 seconds of simulation.

Currently simbody does not pass the test (#989).

values.description:
Smooth edges by increasing from 2x2 to 3x3 PCF shadow map texture sampling, and added interpolation.

Code adapted from [here](
http://www.ogre3d.org/forums/viewtopic.php?f=1&t=78834).  Converted to glsl, and lightened shadow factor to match gazebo's original shadow color

See [screenshot](https://www.dropbox.com/s/aq31fn5bxa8yxx2/pcf_shadows.png) for comparison.

values.title: test for issue #624 in gazebo_2.0 branch
Refactor physics::SurfaceParams class to ODESurfaceParams, BulletSurfaceParams, etc

summary.html:
Currently, the physics::SurfaceParams class contains a bunch of ODE-specific parameters. Bullet uses two of these parameters (mu, mu2) and simbody uses none. Friction parameters can only be specified for simbody as global defaults in SimbodyPhysics. So this is the first in a sequence of pull requests to enable surface parameters for each physics engine.

This pull request moves the ODE-specific parameters from SurfaceParams to ODESurfaceParams and also creates a BulletSurfaceParams class. The SurfaceParams class retains two high-level parameters: collideWithoutContact and collideWithoutContactBitmask.

I also add a function to the collision class for each physics engine that allows access to the surface parameters for that engine:

In ODECollision.hh:

/// \brief Similar to Collision::GetSurface, but provides dynamically
///        casted pointer to ODESurfaceParams.
/// \return Dynamically casted pointer to ODESurfaceParams.
public: ODESurfaceParamsPtr GetODESurface() const;

In BulletCollision.hh:

/// \brief Similar to Collision::GetSurface, but provides dynamically
///        casted pointer to BulletSurfaceParams.
/// \return Dynamically casted pointer to BulletSurfaceParams.
public: BulletSurfaceParamsPtr GetBulletSurface() const;

There's a lot of changed code, but the goal here is pure refactoring, no changes in behavior. It does break the API for SurfaceParams, but it seemed like it would be too messy to try to deprecate and move everything.

values.description: The `Base::childrenEnd` variable was being used as a cache for the end of a vector, but this was causing some segfaults on the latest version of Mac OSX (#965). All comparisons with `Base::childrenEnd` were removed in pull request #857 and pull request #881, which were targeted to the gazebo_1.9 branch. This pull request removes the now unused variable from default to preserve ABI on the release branches.
values.title: Remove unused Base::childrenEnd

This pull request removes the now unused variable from default to preserve ABI on the release branches.
